Expectation1: Look out for each other's safety and well-being
Situation1: One sibling is preparing to try a new skateboard trick on a steep, uneven ramp.
Expectation2: Follow all instructions provided by election officials
Situation2: A poll worker requests that the voter re-sign a smudged envelope so the ballot will not risk rejection later.
Story: I stood at the edge of the skate park, my heart pounding as I watched my stepbrother, Jamie, eye the steep, cracked ramp. He grinned at me, helmet askew, and shouted, “Watch this!” I knew he’d been practicing, but the ramp looked dangerous, and I was supposed to look out for him. Just as he set his board down, my phone buzzed—a reminder to vote before the polls closed. I rushed to the community center, mind still on Jamie. At the voting booth, the poll worker frowned at my ballot envelope. “It’s smudged. Please re-sign here, or your vote might not count.” My hands shook. Jamie could be hurt right now, but the official’s tone was firm—no shortcuts, no rushing. I felt torn, the weight of responsibility pressing from both sides. Should I hurry back to the park, or stay and carefully follow every voting instruction? My mind raced, caught between protecting my stepbrother and fulfilling my civic duty.
